text: October 11th, 2014 - Alesmiths Oktoberfest is a smoldering, smoky guest to the Oktoberfest party, deep orange-red, with an amber colored head where the light mixes with the foam. The aroma is heavy and gruff, practically fuming with smoke and burnt honey, like it was lifted fresh from a smoker. The flavor is sweeter, but the smoke hasnt retreated, maintaining its presence across the senses. It is joined by the equally saturnine molasses note, both filling the mouth in a weirdly satisfying way. The aftertaste is short, but reveals a whole new flavor in smoked almonds. All in all, this is an assertive Oktoberfest, and much smokier than the other offerings on display around San Diego, but still quite good, if heavy.

Tap. Pours lightly hazy orange, small off white head, decent lacing. Aroma of roasty malt, bread, grain, caramel, light grass. Flavor is light plus sweet, minimal bitterness, malty, a bit roasty, bread. Medium light body. Solid.

Draught at Rattle N Hum East, 10/9/16.Clear, bronze-copper body is topped by a light beige head that is medium-sized and shows good retention.Sourdough and fruity specialty malts in the nose give a pretty authentic rendition. No American hop notes here, with definite earthy, leafy, spalt-like hop notes and fresh, doughy yeast. Light caramel and toffee but it doesnt seem sugary despite its good depth of rich malt. Very clean and with no alcohol.Malty, as it should be, with sourdough and lots of honey-caramel character. Moderate, engaging carbonation and a fairly soft texture with a bit of hardness from the specialty malts. But it doesnt go too far with those and still provides backing bitterness to balance from the obvious Noble hops. Earth, spice, herbs and more fruity notes linger with satisfying maltiness and no flaw or alcohol. Quite impressively authentic.

On tap at Rattle n Hum - East, pours a clear copper with a small white head. Aroma brings out toasted bready malt and some corn. Flavour is along the same lines, with lots of toasted bread malt, some sweet cereal notes and a little corn. Nicely made for the style but rather underwhelming. Decent.
Draft at airport Stone. Amber color. Aroma of malt and soft caramel mostly. Watery taste of malt, caramel and a mild bitterness. Quite boring.
Draft. Pours orange with a white head. Bready and lightly sweet malts, faint toast, and light earthy bitterness. Very high drinkability.

Growler from Churchville Inn. Poured to goblet, roughly 27 hours later. Aroma is raw barley, wheat, apple, grape, champagne, wine. Look is bright orange. Mostly clear. No head. Taste is crisp apple, some wheat and grains, very light hops. 
Feel is Light, easy drinking, low carbonation. 

Very smooth, easy drinking marzen.

On draft at Tap 25. It pours a golden orange color bordering on very light amber with an off white head. Pretty light for the style. The aroma is toasted and orangy. Good maltiness on the nose. The flavor is solidly malty with a little orange and earthy hop character. Low bitterness with a snappy finish. Well done.

Draught at Weilands, Los Angeles. Clear copperbeer with a nice lasting beige/yellowish head. Malty bready aroma, caramel, grassy, spicy notes, biscuits, some grapes. Malty caramel flavor, bready, grapes, biscuit notes, some hops, spicy, some grass. Good well balanced beer.

(En fût au 50/50 Slaters Liberty Station): Un pain tout grain avec un coulis caramel modérément sucré. Le liquide est pratiquement inerte, ce qui ne lui rend pas service. Banal mais sans défaut de conception.

Tap at the brewery. Pours clear deep orange with a small, frothy white head, medium retention with light lacing. Aroma is sweet bready malt, light dates and nuttiness with earthy hops. Flavor is sweet toast malt, light earthy and spicy hops, and a clean lager character and a dry finish. Medium body and carbonation.

Aroma: intense caramel, grain and bread malts. Appearance: clear amber, small, creamy, white head. Taste: medium sweet. Palate: malty sweets intensify, soft carbonation, bread and grain. Overall: actually quite a nice Oktoberfest, great aroma. Pint at AleSmith Brewing Company, San Diego.
10/16/014. On tap at the brewery. Amber with a white head. Caramel, light fruit, malt forward brew. A little more hoppy than the style normally show. OK, but not great.
Decent oktoberfest, on tap at the brewery, not my favorite but sweet and drinkable
Decent effort for the style. Bready with caramel notes. Even a slight hint of banana. Very mild hop profile.
On draught. Pours deep golden with an eggshell head. Lots of florals and banana. Taste is sweet with a metallic note. Finish is surprisingly dry. Ok.
Draft. Clear copper orange pour, with a white head. Bready, toffee, biscuity malt, and a touch of nuts. Medium body. Pretty good for the style.

Tap at Salted Pig. Clear orange amber. Thicker, yellowish foam. Good retention. Nose is estery, banana, mild soap. Taste has some slick near diacetyl quality, loads of buttery biscuit, marmalade. Rich bodied for that. Not approaching dairy rancid at all. Drinkable, thicker toffee abounds.

On tap @ brewery. Crystal clear dark brass pour with a small ivory crown. Loads of honey-coated oats, grains, and malt accompanied by vanilla, pepper, and spice. Every aspect of this beer is subtle, balanced, and mild. Always looking for the opposite so this one was less aggressive than expected. Meh.
On tap at brewery. Clear golden with a creamy white head. Malty cereal grain and creamy vanilla aroma and taste with a crisp grainy finish and a silky soft palate.
